content:
hello! is there any place i can find a syntax overview of lean, and/or all of the primitive types? even if it's just a list of keywords

right now i'm trying to figure out if there is an equivalent of rust's todo!() (sorry does not seem to work in a def context). i tried to track this down by looking for a list of keywords at first, but couldn't find any, and then tried to track it down by looking for terms of something like the Never type, but couldn't find lean's equivalent type.

i think i'm looking for these two pages but for lean 4, basically:

  • https://leanprover.github.io/reference/lexical_structure.html
  • https://leanprover.github.io/reference/expressions.html

I don't know of a good reference (and my rust is pretty amateur level so I don't know what todo!() does specifically) -- it's complicated because Lean's syntax is of course extensible at runtime -- but will just point out that sorry can indeed work for data, Lean just needs to know the type -- e.g. def f : Nat := sorry works. So perhaps could also share a #mwe if you have some example that doesn't seem to work.
ah ty! it was indeed def lacking a type

i'm still curious about if there is a syntactic reference though... i struggle with knowing where to look for the documentation/implementation of something because i can't always tell whether it is a primitive construct or a syntax construct. same goes for types
In VS Code you can "go to definition" and "go to declaration" for pretty much anything. The second one gives you the syntax definition. Every piece of syntax is declared in Lean somewhere.
woah, extremely cool!
https://lean-lang.org/documentation/ has more up-to-date references than that Lean 3 documentation that you mentioned, but the reference manual is still a work in progress.
i see... yeah, i've been bait-and-switched a couple of times now from the reference manual having an entry on something i was curious about and the page then being empty :pensive:
is there any reason the mathlib docs page (also, why are they called mathlib docs?) isn't linked to on the documentation page?
Mathlib is a community project, whereas the page you referenced is one maintained by the language developers (the Lean FRO more specifically).
ah i see
i guess my last question is, is there a place that lists all the builtin types?

The builtin types are pretty much the same as the ones from Lean 3. Here's the mathlib3 docs page: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/foundational_types.html (it's Type u/Prop and pi types)
If you mean what's defined in the prelude, then you can look at the mathlib4 documentation, in the Init section.
thanks, i think that's what i'm looking for

though interestingly Bot is defined as a class (?) and in mathlib (??). do you know why that is? i would have expected it to be a primitive or defined in terms of Pi or something (i forget the exact encoding)

There are analogues of never, but the concept needs to change for Lean. There's, for example, the panic function (used via the panic! macro) whose return type is anything (which for math reasons we require to be anything that's Inhabited), but whose runtime semantics are to halt the program.

Functions can't have side effects in Lean, but in a monadic context you can throw errors with things like throwError/failure/etc. These also return something of any type, modeling the fact that it can't return at all.
Bot is the bottom of a mathematical lattice. It's not the bot you might be familiar with in Haskell types.
(Lean's types don't have that kind of bot. All pure functions must terminate.)
oh very cool! tysm
